issues.title: Missing -webkit-user-select prefix for Safari compatibility in [data-sonner-toast][data-swiped=true]
issues.body:
###  Bug Report

In production builds of my project (React 19 / Vite 7 / Sonner 2.0.7), Edge‚Äôs compatibility audit flags a missing vendor prefix in Sonner‚Äôs toast swipe selector. This issue affects Safari compatibility and appears in the generated CSS bundle, not just in development.

---

#### Audit Output
```

'user-select' is not supported by Safari. Add '-webkit-user-select' to support Safari 3+.
[data-sonner-toast][data-swiped=true] {
user-select: none;
}
Request: [http://localhost:4173/dashboard](http://localhost:4173/dashboard)

````

---

#### Affected Browser(s)
* Safari (desktop and iOS WebView)
* Verified via Edge Compatibility Tool (Version 131+)

---

#### Environment
```json
{
  "sonner": "^2.0.7",
  "react": "^19.2.0",
  "vite": "^7.1.8",
  "node": ">=22.18",
  "browserslist": [
    "chrome >= 90",
    "firefox >= 88",
    "safari >= 15.4",
    "edge >= 90"
  ]
}
````

This occurs in **production builds**.

---

#### Suggested Fix

Add the missing Safari prefix for `user-select` in the toast swipe selector:

```css
[data-sonner-toast][data-swiped=true] {
  -webkit-user-select: none; /* Safari 3+ */
  user-select: none;
}
```

---

#### References

* [[MDN: user-select](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/user-select)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/user-select)
* [[webhint.io explanation](https://webhint.io/docs/user-guide/hints/hint-compat-api-css/)](https://webhint.io/docs/user-guide/hints/hint-compat-api-css/)

---

#### Why It Matters

Safari still requires the `-webkit-` prefix for full support of `user-select`.
Adding this line prevents text-selection behavior inconsistencies when dismissing toasts via swipe gestures in Safari or iOS embedded browsers.

It also clears audit warnings in Edge, Lighthouse, and CI environments that validate CSS compatibility.

issues.title: feat: toaster transition duration option
issues.body:
üöÄ What's Changed
This PR introduces a new configuration option to the Toaster component, allowing users to control the speed of the transition animation.
- Added a transitionDuration property (Number in milliseconds) to the toastOptions object.
- This property dictates how long the toast's enter and exit animations (transitions) will last.

üí° Why This is Needed
As discussed in #690, the animation duration was previously fixed, which limited flexibility when integrating the component into different design systems.

This option resolves that by allowing developers to set the animation speed globally, ensuring the toast's appearance is perfectly synchronized with their application's UX flow‚Äîwhether they need a lightning-fast notification or a leisurely slide-in.

üîß How to Use
The duration can be set within the toastOptions when rendering the <Toaster /> component:

```js
<Toaster
  toastOptions={{
    // Set the transition duration to 400ms
    transitionDuration: 400,
  }}
/>
```
- Default: (State the current hardcoded default duration, e.g., 400ms)
- Unit: Milliseconds (ms)

issues.title: Feature Request - Add a countdown progress bar to visualize toast duration
issues.body:
### üöÄ Feature Request: Countdown Progress Bar for Toast Duration

**Description**
Add an optional **countdown progress bar** (or radial timer) to toasts, which visually indicates how much time is left before the toast auto-dismisses. This would improve UX by giving users a clear sense of urgency and control over the toast's lifecycle.

---

**Motivation**

* Many toast libraries (e.g., React Hot Toast, Material UI Snackbar) provide a progress bar to show dismissal timing.
* A visual indicator helps users decide whether to interact with the toast (e.g., click an action button) before it disappears.
* Enhances accessibility and reduces surprise when a toast vanishes unexpectedly.

---

**Proposed API**

```tsx
toast("Your file was uploaded!", {
  duration: 5000,
  showProgress: true, // Enables countdown progress bar
  progressColor: "#22c55e" // Optional customization
});
```

**Possible Options**

* `showProgress: boolean` ‚Üí toggle progress indicator.
* `progressColor?: string` ‚Üí customize bar color (default matches toast accent).
* `progressPosition?: "top" | "bottom" | "inside"` ‚Üí optional placement.

---

**Benefits**

* More intuitive feedback.
* Aligns Sonner with familiar patterns from other libraries.
* Lightweight addition that can be opt-in, preserving minimalism.

issues.title: Is there a way to update a toast and change its' toastId?
issues.body:
We have the following use case:

A user can click on a button that creates an order. We start showing a toast while that is happening. At this time, we don't have a proper id, so we don't pass an id to the toast but generate and store the id in a ref. When the order is created, we update the toast passing in said order to show more accurate data about what was created (update by passing the previously created id). 

We receive events that should trigger the same toast when the status of an order changes, which can happen while the original toast is still active. We don't want to have duplicated toasts, so we try to use the orderId as a toastId. The problem we have is that when we create the toast initially, it doesn't use the orderId as the toast id and we would have to track that separately, which is not ideal.

A solution to this would be to remove the original toast and create the new one but that triggers animations.
A better solution, in my opinion, would be to be able to update the id of the toast.

issues.title: feat(toaster): add support for multiple toasters with unique identifiers
issues.body:
### Summary

This PR adds support for rendering and targeting multiple Toaster components in the app. You can now:

- Render multiple `<Toaster />` instances, each with a unique `id` prop.
- Target toasts to a specific Toaster by passing a `toasterId` option to the `toast()` API.
- Closes #222

### Usage

```jsx
<Toaster id="global" position="top-right" />
<Toaster id="canvas" position="bottom-left" />

<button onClick={() => toast('Global toast', { toasterId: 'global' })}>
  Show in Global Toaster
</button>
<button onClick={() => toast('Canvas toast', { toasterId: 'canvas' })}>
  Show in Canvas Toaster
</button>
```

### API

- `<Toaster id="your-id" />` ‚Äî Renders a Toaster instance with a unique id.
- `toast('Message', { toasterId: 'your-id' })` ‚Äî Shows the toast only in the Toaster with the matching id.
- Toasts without a `toasterId` will appear in the default/global Toaster (no id).

### Backward Compatibility

- Existing usage with a single Toaster and no ids is fully supported and unchanged.

issues.title: Cannot find module `sonner/dist/styles.css?url` after upgrading to v2.0.4
issues.body:
**Description**
After upgrading Sonner from v2.0.3 to v2.0.4, the build fails with the following error:

```
Cannot find module 'sonner/dist/styles.css?url'
```

Prior to this release, importing styles worked correctly. It appears that the path or packaging of the CSS file was changed in v2.0.4.

It seems likely that the new release either removed or relocated `dist/styles.css`, but the documentation (and/or code) still expects to import it from `sonner/dist/styles.css?url`.

**To Reproduce**

1. In your project, update `package.json` to use:

   ```json
   "dependencies": {
     "sonner": "2.0.4",
     /* ...other dependencies... */
   }
   ```
2. Run your package manager to install the new version:

   ```bash
   npm install
   # or
   yarn install
   ```
3. In your application code, import the styles exactly as before. For example:

   ```js
   import { Toaster } from "sonner";
   import "sonner/dist/styles.css?url";
   ```

  or
  
  ```js
  import sonnerStyles from 'sonner/dist/styles.css?url';
  ```
4. Start the dev server or build your application:

   ```bash
   npm run dev
   # or
   yarn dev
   # or however you build
   ```
5. Observe the error in the console/terminal:

   ```
   Cannot find module 'sonner/dist/styles.css?url'
   ```

**Expected Behavior**

* The CSS file should still be available at the same path (`sonner/dist/styles.css`) so that importing it using the `?url` suffix works as before.
* After upgrading, no import-related errors should occur, and the toast component should continue rendering with the correct default styling.

**Actual Behavior**

* The import of `sonner/dist/styles.css?url` fails because the file is not found in the published `dist/` directory of the 2.0.4 package.
* As a result, the application build crashes, preventing usage of the Sonner Toaster and any related styling.

issues.title: Challenges by customizing sonner
issues.body:
Thanks for the great work on Sonner. I've been using it for a long time and really appreciate how seamless and reliable it is out of the box.

For a recent project, I decided to go beyond the defaults and deeply customize Sonner‚Äôs appearance and behavior. I wanted to share some experience insights from that process, as I ran into a few challenges that I think could be worth considering for future improvements.

1. Overriding styles on the default Toaster
My first approach was to use the Toaster component and override styles directly. While this technically works, I often found myself adding redundant or even "nullifying" utility classes to undo the default styles. This is partly due to the lack of class merging utilities like clsx or tailwind-merge, which makes precise customization more cumbersome than it should be.

2. Then i tried to use unstyled=true. And then i git the point of some of internal elements not being reachable directly. 

3. Using a custom toast component
Next, I tried building a fully custom toast component. Visually, this gave me what I wanted, but it came with trade-offs:

I lost access to some of the built-in methods, like .promise, which are pretty valuable.

More critically, certain fundamental aesthetic behaviors didn‚Äôt translate well. For example: stacking a short toast on top of a long one no longer behaves as expected. See [this repro](https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-1mbzjcdt?file=app%2Fpage.tsx)

issues.title: Headless Toasts Do Not Recalculate Slot Size on Update, Causing Overlap and Layout Issues
issues.body:
When a state change is passed to a promise toast, the "slot" size is updated to account for potential size changes. This causes the toasts to spread out evenly so they don't overlap or get unnecessary gaps between them. This is not true for state changes on headless toasts. If the toast() function is called with an `id` to update the state of a headless toast, the "slots" that the toasts are assigned in the stack of toasts does not reflect any new size updates, causing the toasts to overlap. 

I am testing out this library for a large scale web application. We are currently implementing a work-around to this issue by giving the affected toasts a large enough size to account for any potential state changes. However, we would love to see this issue resolved. 

Here's an [example](https://v0.dev/chat/button-toast-updates-yQ0ZMN9Q08n?b=b_r4Fx4OUBqkU&p=0) in V0 where the unwanted behavior is reproduced, along with a couple of gifs that illustrate the problem:

# Bug Report: Dynamic Toaster height causes incorrect position calculation  

## Description  
Currently, the Toaster does not properly support dynamic height adjustments when its content changes. As a result, its position is incorrectly calculated, leading to visual misalignment.  

## Current Behavior  
The Toaster remains positioned based on its initial height, leading to incorrect placement when the content height increases or decreases.  

## Expected Behavior  
The Toaster should recalculate its `--initial-height` and `--offset` when its height changes due to content updates.  

## Steps to Reproduce  
1. Render three Toasters.  
2. Wait for additional content to appear dynamically.  
3. Hover over the Toasters and observe that the animation is broken due to incorrect position calculations.  

## Reproduction Environment  
A minimal reproduction can be found here:  
[Codesandbox Example](https://codesandbox.io/p/sandbox/toast-sonner-forked-3jkq3s)

This PR introduces a new `showCloseOnHover` option for toasts, enhancing user interaction flexibility, and also fixes an existing test case for improved reliability.

#### **Testing**
- Verified that the `showCloseOnHover` option behaves as expected in different scenarios:
  - Close button always visible when `showCloseOnHover` is `false` or unspecified.

issues.title: fix: prevent double custom toast counter increase when initial id is undefined
issues.body:
## Problem:
When creating a custom wrapper around Sonner `custom` toast i have encountered an issue with toast updating.  
Despite providing proper id to the second invocation, second toast was created, instead of an update to the existing one.

After skimming trough the code, i have noticed that the generated `id` was overwritten in case of `id: undefined`.
In that case `toastsCounter` was increased again inside `create`, despite originally created id being returned from the function, creating id mismatch.

## Fix:
Changed the parameter order when calling `create` from `custom`, so generated id would not be overwritten by `data.id` being set to `undefined`.

Also added regression test.

issues.title: Make swipe to dismiss discoverable
issues.body:
I understand that Sonner intentionally restricts swipe-to-dismiss to the same direction the toast came from, as described in [Issue #407](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/issues/407) and [Issue #274](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/issues/274). The limitation to down-only dismissing makes the action difficult to discover, as highlighted in [Issue #141](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/issues/141), and likely also motivated the aforementioned issues.

I initially thought there was no swipe-to-dismiss feature, and was confused by its mention in the documentation because I was only trying to swipe to the sides. It was not intuitive for me to try swiping down, and it‚Äôs an uncomfortable gesture, especially since the toasts are close to the bottom edge, requiring an awkward thumb movement for single-handed use.

Therefore, I respectfully request you to reconsider adding left/right swipe to dismiss. This is an important caveat in an otherwise amazing library. I apologize if this turns out to be unworthy of your time, but I genuinely believe in the merits of this suggestion.

## The Case for Left/Right Dismiss

I understand the main motivation for the current implementation is spatial consistency. However, I disagree that swiping left/right to dismiss violates this consistency.

Quoting the [Designing Fluid Interfaces](https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2018/803/) presentation, which I believe underpins this decision:

> So, if something disappears one way, we expect it to emerge from where it came, right? If I walked off this stage this way and then emerged that way, you'd be amazed because that's impossible. We wanted to play into this consistent sense of space. So, if something is going out of view and coming back into view, it should do so in symmetric paths.

This principle would be applicable if the same toast were to reappear. However, toasts are ephemeral notifications; dismissing them to the sides does not break spatial expectations. In fact, it can emphasize the different identities of toasts, even with identical content.

There seems to be a misconception that toasts are stable UI elements like a dock or sidebar, hence requiring consistent entry and exit paths. The more fitting metaphor for notifications is the "stack of cards":

- They stack.
- You can fan them out to see details.
- You swipe them to the sides to remove them.

This card metaphor is extensively used in mainstream touch interfaces (e.g., notifications on Android/iOS). Sonner aligns with this metaphor since toasts stack, are fannable, and can be swiped away.

## Alternatives to Improve Discoverability
If the above argument doesn‚Äôt persuade you, I still believe the issue of discoverability needs addressing. Here are some alternative solutions:

### Dropzone Visual Affordance

Adding a dropzone visual affordance when a finger is held over a toast could give users a clear target for dismissing. This could be a faint glow/shadow on the edge where dismissed toasts are directed.

### Lifting the Toast on Touch

Another option is to lift the toast from the page by increasing the vertical offset of its shadow when touched. Currently, there's no indication that a toast supports gestures when a user holds their finger over it. This visual affordance could nudge users to try other gestures, even if it doesn't explicitly indicate the need to swipe down.

issues.title: fix: add "main" entry to package.json
issues.body:
### Issue:

Closes https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/issues/456

### What has been done:

- [x] Adds "main" entry in package.json

According to [Node.js documentation](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#package-entry-points) only on older versions of Node.js should `main` be required.

> For new packages targeting the currently supported versions of Node.js, the ["exports"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#exports) field is recommended. For packages supporting Node.js 10 and below, the ["main"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#main) field is required. If both ["exports"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#exports) and ["main"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#main) are defined, the ["exports"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#exports) field takes precedence over ["main"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#main) in supported versions of Node.js.

~Regardless, Parcel doesn't seem to honor the sole existence of `exports` (without `main`). This change will support both by allowing `exports` to take precedence per the above.~

UPDATE: Seems like the issue could be due to [conditional exports](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#conditional-exports) not [supported in Parcel](https://github.com/parcel-bundler/parcel/issues/8221#issuecomment-1159092245). I think this is good justification to add the `main` entry as a fallback for when conditional exports is not supported (like in the case of Parcel).

issues.title: Bundle size could be improved 300% by getting rid of DOMPurify
issues.body:
[Payload](https://github.com/payloadcms/payload) is currently using react-toastify. Would love to switch to sonner, but it comes with a noticeable bundle size increase - and we are trying to keep it low.

So I did some research as for _why_ sonner's bundle size is larger - the source code itself is super nice and clean. We'll consider including the src of a [trimmed version of sonner](https://github.com/AlessioGr/sonner-zero) within payload and using that for now, to benefit from the smaller bundle size. Here are my findings:

## DOMPurify

The DOMPurify package TRIPLES your bundle size. Removing DOMPurify from your codebase brings down the gzipped bundled js size from 14kb to 5kb.

And all it does is sanitize input strings of toast titles and descriptions, IF html provided. Within our app, we know we will never want to toast html, and we have full control over what we're toasting out. If we do want to toast out html, we can sanitize it ourselves.

It might be worth the bundle bundle size improvement to consider removing it and, in your docs, advising the users who provide html to sanitize it themselves. They might already have a library for html sanitization installed & bundled in their project!

issues.title: BUG: Invalid WAI-ARIA setup preventing screen readers from announcing new toasts
issues.body:
### Describe the feature / bug üìù:
New toasts are not announced when using some screen readers like window's narrator (`ctrl+Start+Enter` on Windows 10/11) as well as old versions of iOS's VoiceOver

### Steps to reproduce the bug üîÅ:
1. Open Windows 10 narrator by clicking `ctrl+Start+Enter`
2. Click a button that opens a toast
3. See that the toast is not being announced

### Why this is happening:
The problem occurs due to the ARIA setup of the toasts and how some screen readers handle ARIA live regions:
- Each toast is wrapped with an `li` element with `role="status"`
- That `li` element is only present in the HTML when there's a toast and is removed when there's no toast
- This is the root cause of this bug because ARIA live regions should always be present on screen so that screen readers can subscribe to their changes in order to announce future changes, so by conditionally rendering the live region causes some ("dumb") screen readers to miss the changes of the live region therefore not announcing it

### Solution:
1. We can go the radix-ui route and have a separate element with `role="status"` that is always present in the HTML and the content of the latest toast will be injected to that element
2. Or we can move the `role="status"` to the `section` (which is always present in the HTML) and explicitly add `aria-relevant="additions text"` to only announce additions and not removals and also explicitly add `aria-atomic="false"` to not re-read all the toasts when a new toast is added but rather only the changes
3. Another suggestion is to allow consumers of the lib to provide their own ARIA props to the `section` element as well as to the `ol` and `li` elements in order to customize the looks / functionality and most importantly the ARIA settings (like changing the `aria-label` to the website's language, because right now it's hard coded to `notifications alt+t` which in case you use a language that is not English it will make your site violate WGAC a11y rules which are required by law in some regions, states and countries)

issues.title: Enhancement Request: Scrollable Sonner
issues.body:
I've run into cases where having a scrollable toast area would really improve usability, especially on smaller screens where toasts can overflow.

## Feature Request
It would be great to have a scrollable toast notification area as a feature. This would be super useful when there are more toasts than can fit on the screen, letting users scroll to see all active toasts without missing any important ones.

## Implementation Suggestions
- **Scrollable Toast Container:** Make the toast area scrollable when toasts exceed available space
- **Customizable Scroll Options:** Allow customizing scroll behavior (max height before enabling, scroll speed, etc)
- **Responsive Design:** Make sure scrolling works well, is usable across device sizes and mobile
- **Accessibility:**  Include keyboard navigation, etc

## Use Case
This would help in situations where lots of toasts get generated quickly, like during busy times in a monitoring app. The scrollable area prevents the screen from getting overloaded and toasts getting hidden.

## Potential Challenges
- Smooth scrolling without interfering with toast functions
- Balancing visibility duration and scrollability

I think this would really improve the UX when toast overflow happens, especially on smaller screens. It makes sure users don't miss notifications due to limited space. Let me know if you have any other thoughts!

issues.title: Make `PromiseData` partial in `toast.promise`
issues.body:
üëã

We use Sonner together with React Query. Our `queryClient` automatically shows an error toast when a request fails (and some other cond. are met). When making mutations, we use `toast.promise` to show the `loading` and `success` states ‚Äî since errors are handled elsewhere, we don't even bother.

What I'm proposing is changing `PromiseData`

```ts
<ToastData>(promise: PromiseT<ToastData>, data?: PromiseData<ToastData>) => string | number;
```

To the following:

```ts
<ToastData>(promise: PromiseT<ToastData>, data?: Partial<PromiseData<ToastData>>) => string | number;
```

This would not only make `error` optional, but all the other properties too.

issues.title: feat: Add RTL support
issues.body:
This PR introduces RTL (Right-to-Left) support for the `Toaster` component.

![direction](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/assets/24194621/0874e461-c882-441a-b1b0-1aa8c18327a7)


**Related Issues**
- #108

#### Changes:

1. RTL adjustments for SVG icons within the `Toaster`.
2. Corrected Acton button margins for RTL layout in `Toaster`.
3. Support RTL through `<html dir='rtl'>`
4. Support RTL through `<Toaster dir='rtl' />`
5. dir attributes are `rtl`, `ltr`, `auto`
6. Headless example changed to support rtl (through Toaster or html)

**Priority of direction (`dir`) :**
1. Toaster
2. html
3. if both not set, default to `ltr`

```jsx
<Toaster dir="ltr" />
<Toaster dir="auto" /> // html direction or ltr
<Toaster dir="rtl" />
<Toaster /> // html direction or ltr
```

 ```tsx
<html dir="rtl">
<html dir="ltr">
```

I know we can hack this with CSS, but it's so much nicer to have it built-in. Saves us from redoing it in every project.

issues.title: Support multiple toast instances
issues.body:
I faced some problem with `react-hot-toast` and was looking for a library with similar API, then found this. Smooth transitions, simple codebase, Awesome work!!

## About this PR

This PR introduce `create()` function that returns `<Toaster >` & `toast`. As well as refactoring `state.ts` & `index.tsx` to support this.

https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/assets/30023628/a4414150-84c7-4826-9c15-ea54bfca509e

video via [demo branch](https://github.com/thihathit/sonner/tree/multiple-toast-instance-demo)

## Motivation

Lately i've face issue with `singleton` states sharing across dependencies. Especially when parent project uses `sonner` and one of it's third-party library also used `sonner`. This is due to how package managers optimize it's dependencies.

The new `create` function will enable another way of keeping the state on consuming codebase instead of `sonner` library's singleton state. This will also benefit to users who'd like to have multiple instances of `sonner`.

Issue reproduction:
- [Branch](https://stackblitz.com/github/thihathit/sonner/tree/singleton-issue)
- [Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/github/thihathit/sonner/tree/singleton-issue?file=website/app/page.tsx)

### Note

I didn't add E2E tests since i don't have much time. sorry about that üòÖ

* Issue

I want to render a toast whenever an error message changes, for that I am using **useEffect** hook, but the console prompts this warning:

_Warning: flushSync was called from inside a lifecycle method. React cannot flush when React is already rendering. Consider moving this call to a scheduler task or micro task_

* How to replicate

This PR adds the ability to specify classNames to use for the description. You can either set the descriptionClassName on the `<Toaster/>` component or on individual toasts.

This is super handy for Tailwind users. For example:

```tsx
toast('The thing was successful', {
  description: 'Here\'s some additional info about the thing',
  className: 'font-medium text-gray-800',
  descriptionClassName: 'font-normal text-gray-500'
});

or

```tsx
<Toaster toastOptions={{descriptionClassName: 'font-normal text-gray-500'}} />

> Could you elaborate?

Using `:where([data-sonner-toast])` instead of `[data-sonner-toast]` will allow consumers to easily override lib styles using CSS frameworks similar to tailwind or using their own classes because `:where` has 0 specificity, even if lib styles come later they will be overridden by consumer styles

comments.body:
You should try to use the `style` option as much as possible as that's the easiest way to override the default styling, classes need a higher specificity level which can be achieved with `!important` or just adding more selectors for example. 
That's not ideal when you are using Sonner with tailwind for example, but in that case you probably want to customize the toast even more (lose the default styling) which the [headless](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner#headless) option allows.

comments.body:
There is a way to silence errors, but are you sure section isn't the more appropriate element?

**The native element equivalent of `<div role="region">` is `<section>` according to...**
https://html-validate.org/rules/prefer-native-element.html

> "While WAI-ARIA describes many roles which can provide semantic information about what the element represents. Support for roles is varying and since HTML5 has many native equivalent elements it is better to use the native when possible."


Role | Element
-- | --
... | ...
radio | input
**region** | **section**
table | table
... | ...

**Sections does not need a heading according to...**
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/section#using_a_section_without_a_heading

> "The `<section>` element represents a generic standalone section of a document, which doesn't have a more specific semantic element to represent it. Sections should always have a heading, **with very few exceptions.**"

**Update: But...**
> "If you are only using the element as a styling wrapper, use a div instead."

... and if the element only is a styling wrapper, then maybe it shouldn't have the role "region"?

comments.body:
Hi @joaom00 - Thanks for taking the time to review!

> I think we can refactor to use logical properties
> Some alignments are incorrect

I just checked again and it appears to work on Firefox but not Chrome!  
I'll see what I can do.

 >   Add `dir` type to `Toaster` props

Actually, that was my first approach but I realized I'll need to pass `dir='rtl'` to both:
1. `Toaster`: since I assume will be defaulting the direction prop as LTR. 
2. `html`: since that's usually the default way of enabling RTL

Beside, that can be done through the `style` prop:
```tsx
<Toaster
  style={{ direction: 'rtl' }}
/>
```

So I focused on the styling issues for SVG and action button.

Hi @joaom00 , thanks for your comments.
I have added the `dir` as prop to `Toaster` and revamped the styling for readability.

**Priority of `dir` assignment:**
1. Toaster
2. html
3. if both not set, default to `ltr`

**Changes**
- `dir` support for Toaster (ltr and rtl and auto)
- styling icon and button with CSS variables based on directions
- `Headless` example now supports `rtl` (through Toaster or html) 

> and in the website add an option to enable the RTL mode

Once we finalize this as stable, I'll add an example üëç

comments.body:
Seems unnecessary since you can try and catch the promise and call toast based on it

```js
try {
  await myPromise()
  toast.success('Success')
} catch (e) {
  toast.error('Error')
}
```
or by using `.then` and `.catch`

```js
myPromise()
  .then(() => toast.success('Success'))
  .catch((e) => toast.error('Error'))
```

comments.body:
> Well of course (and that is what I am doing), but if that's the general way of thinking, then you could argue that `toast.promise()` is also unnecessary üòè

Not really, the whole idea of `toast.promise` is that it modifies the current toast to some new state after the loading is complete. It's a shortcut to getting a toast id and manually modifying it. So it's pretty useful. Using a try and catch for your case is simple enough since you're only showing a toast after the promise is done, no modifications required to an already existing toast.

Property | Description | Default

description | Toast's description, renders underneath the title. | -
closeButton | Adds a close button which shows on hover. | false
invert | Dark toast in light mode and vice versa. | false
important | Control the sensitivity of the toast for screen readers | false
duration | Time in milliseconds that should elapse before automatically closing the toast. | 4000
position | Position of the toast. | bottom-right
dismissible | If false, it'll prevent the user from dismissing the toast. | true
icon | Icon displayed in front of toast's text, aligned vertically. | -
action | Renders a primary button, clicking it will close the toast. | -
cancel | Renders a secondary button, clicking it will close the toast. | -
id | Custom id for the toast. | -
onDismiss | The function gets called when either the close button is clicked, or the toast is swiped. | -

comments.body:
@X-Vneer I had this exact problem using react-hot-toast. Instead of using setTimeout you can change the order of components in your layout. First the Toaster (the one that renders all the toasts) and then your children (the one with the useEffect).

I think the problem is caused by adding a toast in the useEffect (when Page loads) before the Toaster is even rendered. With setTimeout you are queueing the add toast function at the end of the current JavaScript event stack, so it executes after the Toaster renders.

comments.body:
Overriding position top/right/bottom/left only work if all the toast position are same as the provider default

In this  case, the provider overrided top, right:
```tsx
<Toaster position="top-right" style={{ top: 128, right: 32 }} /> 
```
the default `toast('Event has been created.')` will be ok:
![failed-top-right Large](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/assets/8341625/6781acb7-97c5-48ab-bff5-bd523b34707c)

but if `toast('Event has been created.', { position: 'bottom-right' })`, the group will have top & bottom which created height combine with toast width, it will cover the site with invisible content:
![failed-bottom-right Large](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/assets/8341625/48bbe900-4926-411d-89ec-b69030cab085)


Better just override the css rule which only afftect the corresponding positioned toast

```diff
[data-sonner-toaster][data-y-position=top] {
-   bottom: max(var(--offset), env(safe-area-inset-top));
+   bottom: max(128px, env(safe-area-inset-top));
}
[data-sonner-toaster][data-x-position=right] {
    right: max(var(--offset), env(safe-area-inset-right));
}
```
If you're using Tailwind 

```tsx
<Toaster
      position='top-right'
      className='data-[sonner-toaster]:data-[y-position=top]:top-[max(128px,env(safe-area-inset-top))]' // override offset top to avoid the appbar
/>
```
and this is the result:
![ok-top-right Large](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/assets/8341625/a95c0ca9-04d8-410d-b037-d1ff8dd90974)
![ok-bottom-right Large](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/assets/8341625/0c0d5808-0ef5-4f9c-8c51-1bef6e4ad980)


It would be much much easier and cleaner if we have offsetX offsetY or even better offsetTop, offsetRight, offsetBottom, offsetLeft option.

comments.body:
Hi, I actually was struggling with a similar issue today. I think is just an issue with older `create-react-app` projects, which has trouble interpreting the `exports` field as seen [here](https://github.com/facebook/create-react-app/issues/10892).

This issue is can be resolved by adding:
```
"main": "./dist/index.js",
"module": "./dist/index.mjs",
```
back to `package.json`. These were removed in #136. 

It would be great if these fields could be added back to support older apps.

comments.body:
Hi. I've experienced this issue as well. In our workflow, we're disabling selecting text by default (user pans and interact with a lot of things throughout the app, and having select enabled would cause some weird blue selections sometimes.)
So we have a copyWrapper component that would wrap whatever texts, that can be copied/selected throughout the app. The api we're using is something like this:
```typescript
        <CopyButtonWrapper message={message}>
            {message}
        </CopyButtonWrapper>,
```

This would break default sonner toast layout. 

Our workaround is to wrap what we want to render inside an array:
```typescript
    const copiableMessage = [
        <CopyButtonWrapper message={message} key={"copyWrapper"}>
            {message}
        </CopyButtonWrapper>,
    ];
```

The reason is based on react doc for [isValidelement](https://react.dev/reference/react/isValidElement#caveats) arrays aren't considered valid react element. üòÅ So this would bypass sonner's check. 

cc: @ajmnz 

------

Though @emilkowalski I think this can be added in a non-breaking change to the toast. Just like richColor prop on Toaster component, we can have property named `maintainDefaultLayout` or something similar, and when this option is set to true explicitly, this ternary can change from 
```ts
toast.jsx || React.isValidElement(toast.title) ? (/*bear jsx or title */) : (/*sonner layout */)
```
to 
```ts
toast.jsx || (React.isValidElement(toast.title) && !maintainDefaultLayout) ? (/*bear jsx or title */) : (/*sonner layout */)
```

This is the idea (sound on):

https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/assets/216008/baace819-1ae9-4cbc-8fae-1913945af29d

The thing is, now we can't do the different `aria-live` values of either `polite` or `assertive` using `toast.important` since we're putting the `aria-live` on the section (which may contain multiple toasts). We can make the entire section assertive if any of the underlying toasts are important - I'd argue we don't. Having it assertive might be a very disorienting experience if the screen reader stops mid-sentence to read the toast.

What do you think?

I could open a draft PR we can check. There are quite a few bells and whistles in there (like pointer event, swipping) which I must admit I haven't checked. And I don't have Windows 10 to check the original error. Maybe @FearlessSlug can check?

comments.body:
> I don't fully understand why this is needed, can you explain?

Yep! Suppose we have something like:

```tsx
<Toaster toastOptions={{ unstyled: true, classNames: { title: "text-sm font-heading font-semibold" }}} />
```

then in an individual toast, we want to override some styles:
```tsx
toast("Hello world", { classNames: { title: "text-lg font-bold" }})
```

As-is, there is no easy way to tell if `text-lg` or `text-sm` will take precedence; same with `font-semibold` vs `font-bold`. Sure, we could try to use `!important` but this is not very reliable, and I've also found myself needing to use `!important` in `Toaster` itself (separate issue, see https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/issues/321).

With a custom `cn` function we could guarantee that the classes are merged in a way such that the classes in `toast(...)`  take precedence over classes in `Toaster` when there are classes that target the same attribute. In particular, I'm thinking of the tailwind use case with tailwind-merge, i.e. https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/installation/manual#add-a-cn-helper!

Let me know if this makes sense üôè

comments.body:
I'm not sure this should be closed: yes the snackbars are now clickable, but they cause the Dialog to be closed as they are recognized as outside clicks. To allow click-through we need to consume the internal library [@radix-ui/react-dismissable-layer](https://github.com/radix-ui/primitives/tree/main/packages/react/dismissable-layer) which allows for item for be clicked outside of modality boundaries.

For posterity (and possibly fixing this), I've managed to correctly compose the scope to have both components behave correctly.
Now, my implementation solely uses `toast.custom` as our toast implementation is completely different from what Sonner is offering, so I'm able to do something like:
```tsx
return toast.custom(
  t => (
    <DismissableLayer.Branch asChild>
      <Snackbar    
		...
      />
    </DismissableLayer.Branch>
  ), opts
)
```
considering the current implementation, I'm not quite sure on how this could be achievable using the other methods.

Additionally, we need'd to wrap the `Toaster` component as well:
```tsx
{/* Radix Portal */}
<Portal>
  {/* Allow composability within Radix portals. */}
  <DismissableLayer.Root asChild>
    <Toaster
	...
    />
  </DismissableLayer.Root>
</Portal>
```

But this isn't currently possible, as `Toaster` isn't capable of ref forwarding.

I have opened https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/pull/491 to add the ref forwarding ability, but I'm at a loss on how to allow wrapping the `Toast` element when a custom isn't used.

The issue arises due to the changes to styling made in #377 . 

The button now gets styled with this portion of Tailwind's [preflight css](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/preflight):

```css
/*
1. Correct the inability to style clickable types in iOS and Safari.
2. Remove default button styles.
*/

button,
input:where([type='button']),
input:where([type='reset']),
input:where([type='submit']) {
  -webkit-appearance: button; /* 1 */
  background-color: transparent; /* 2 */
  background-image: none; /* 2 */
}
```

Not exactly sure the proper fix, but the workaround mentioned above works for now.

By the way, here is another solution.

```ts
import styles from './content/style.css?inline'
import styles2 from 'sonner/dist/styles.css?inline'

function addStyle(shadow: ShadowRoot, styles: string[]) {
  const sheets = styles.map((style) => {
    const sheet = new CSSStyleSheet()
    sheet.replaceSync(style.replaceAll(':root', ':host'))
    return sheet
  })
  shadow.adoptedStyleSheets = sheets
}

addStyle(shadow, [styles, styles2])
```

comments.body:
I've stumbled upon this error in a different context. It's because sonner does an _outdated_ check if a promise is a `Promise`.

This is the responsible line of code: [src/state.ts#L124](https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/blob/bc74b2d62c7e0e7533a4a21c7597acefa837f231/src/state.ts#L124)
A promise doesn't need to be an instance of `Promise` to be a promise (yeah ... I know). It only needs to have a .then() method. This [Stackoverflow answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/27746324) has a good summary.
TL;DR: Sonner should use `Promise.resolve(foo)` instead of testing for type.

comments.body:
Personally I avoid libraries that do any sort of script/src injection _because_ of the CSP complications it introduces and instead prefer libraries that force the consumer to manually import the necessary assets (i.e. css) so I can let the bundler handle it with their centralized CSP config.

I do agree that Vite's (and webpack's, and probably any bundler's) CSP approach feels kind of insecure, however, I don't think there's really any viable alternative at the moment. And if you are employing secure CSP rules then it shouldn't matter that scripts can parse the meta tag because the CSP will prevent those scripts from running in the first place. In addition, CSP nonces are (well‚Ä¶ should be) non-deterministic and refreshed on every request, making them impossible to be reused.

comments.body:
I don't think there's a need for passive aggressiveness, Emil is maintaining this in his spare time and is in no way obliged to meet everyone's demands. Nobody's forcing you to use this particular library and you can also fork it.

And to make this a slightly more constructive post, for those in the same CSP boat as myself. When looking at alternatives I've found that many of the toast libraries have exactly the same (embedded) CSS setup as sonner. In that list:
- https://github.com/iamhosseindhv/notistack
- https://github.com/fkhadra/react-toastify
- https://github.com/timolins/react-hot-toast
- https://github.com/pheralb/toast

Of these 4, `react-toastify` provides a dedicated import path that _does not_ do an automatic embedding of the `css` file, see https://github.com/fkhadra/react-toastify/issues/1215. `notistack` and `react-hot-toast` are built on top of https://github.com/cristianbote/goober, which has a built-in CSP workaround that can be used by both libraries to make them work without an `unsafe-inline` CSP directive by basically predefining a `<style nonce="‚Ä¶" id="_goober"></style>` element (see https://github.com/cristianbote/goober/issues/471 and https://github.com/cristianbote/goober/issues/471#issuecomment-1981327546). https://github.com/pheralb/toast sadly has a very similar setup as sonner and cannot be worked around. Personally I'm currently sticking with `react-hot-toast` until `react-aria`'s [Toast](https://react-spectrum.adobe.com/react-aria/Toast.html) component comes out of alpha.

**edit:** I initially mixed up some library names, should be ok now.

> For new packages targeting the currently supported versions of Node.js, the ["exports"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#exports) field is recommended. For packages supporting Node.js 10 and below, the ["main"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#main) field is required. If both ["exports"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#exports) and ["main"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#main) are defined, the ["exports"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#exports) field takes precedence over ["main"](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#main) in supported versions of Node.js.

Regardless, it would nice to support Parcel users by adding a `main` entry like so, as `exports` will take precedence anyways when supported.

```json
"main": "./dist/index.js",
```

I do not want to keep track of IDs so i allow library to generate it.

const id = data?.id || toastsCounter++;

In this piece of code if `id` from `data` is undefined, you increment the counter, but in next line you override it again with undefined.

The reason a toast of type loading does not close is due to the condition set in the code. Specifically, in the Toast component, there are checks to prevent the automatic closing of a loading toast.

https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/blob/2c345fa882919947d22f55ecb1046daf1bfc0ef5/src/index.tsx#L199

This logic ensures that if the toast has a loading type, it will not proceed with the auto-close functionality.

Therefore, it seems that closing is prevented.

**So my opinion is that it doesn't seem to be a bug.**

comments.body:
After further investigation, it seems like Next.js is removing the React import / not changing `Xt` to another React reference and thus causing the error. Found a couple changes that would fix this:

a. Set `minify: false` to tsup config. Obviously not the solution here, but works and helps narrow down the issue.

b. Import directly `isValidElement` instead of `import React from "react"` (ie. `import { isValidElement } from "react"`). The next.js chunk then looks something like:

```js
o = n.then(
  async e => {
    if (a = [
      'resolve',
      e
    ], n.isValidElement(e)) i = !1, // <--- n *is* defined
   // ....
)
``` 

Where `n` is a React reference used by other dependencies too, (ie. `n.useEffect`).

---

Edit: Looks like the issue is fixed on Next.js 14.2.0 onwards.

comments.body:
I found the solution, you need to use `!` which makes tailwindcss utility classes to use css `!important` like:
```
closeButton:
        '-right-1 top-2 left-auto text-teal-500 border-none !hover:bg-teal-500'
```
But this won't work with `hover` or other pseudo-class

I guess selector from this line just have more weight (you can learn about weights [there](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/Specificity))
https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/blob/main/src/styles.css#L248

So I ended up with override of this selector in project `global.css` file:
```
:where([data-sonner-toast]):hover :where([data-close-button]):hover {
    background: none !important;
    border-color: blue !important;
}
```

as you can see in screenshot above, the problem arise when suddenly two versions of react were loaded.

it happened because react just released a 19.1.0 version and esm.sh now suddenly imports it even in older versions of sonner, because it satisfies your package.json

gladly, esm.sh allows to lock it with "deps" parameter, now it works:

```
          "react": "https://esm.sh/react@19.0.0/?dev",
          "react-dom/client": "https://esm.sh/react-dom@19.0.0/client/?dev",

comments.body:
A drawer is a dialog, that blocks interaction with all elements outside of it, as that's how it's supposed to work. Rendering toasts while the dialog is still open is an anti-pattern I would say, but if you really want this to work you can disable `pointer-events: none;` when the drawer is open by setting the `modal` prop to `false` in Vaul.

https://vaul.emilkowal.ski/other#non-modal
comments.author: emilkowalski

comments.body: Rendering something while the dialog is still open seems like an anti-pattern. The dialog blocks interaction with outside elements for a reason. I think the best solution here would be to render the toasts after the dialog is closed.

comments.body:
## Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a component that shows a persistent toast with `duration: Infinity` and a fixed `id`
2. In other parts of the application, try to show regular toast notifications
3. Observe that a single toast call often doesn't show, but multiple consecutive calls will make it appear

## Root Cause Identified

After investigating, I found that the issue occurs when:

1. A persistent toast is actively displayed (with `duration: Infinity`)
2. The toast content is frequently updated (in my case, through a countdown timer)
3. Other components try to display new toasts

It seems like the toast manager in v2.0.1 has issues handling new toast requests while a persistent toast is being updated.

## How I  planed to fixed It

1. Reduced the frequency of updating the persistent toast (only updating at key intervals)
2. Added explicit toast dismissal before showing new toasts
3. Added proper cleanup when the component unmounts

## Additional Context

This issue doesn't appear in earlier versions of sonner (pre-2.0). The problem specifically appears when using `duration: Infinity` together with frequent content updates to the same toast.

comments.body:
> Try putting `<Toaster />` in a different file. In my case I have it in a different component. If I have the exact setup like you did here, it works, but there's no enter animation. The style tag needs to be in the head ideally to make everything work.

This is related to the rendering position. If the Toaster component is rendered early enough, this issue will not occur, regardless of whether the CSS is injected into the head tag. svelte-sonner has a similar problem: if the Toaster component is not placed at the top of the root component, then `toast.info('Hello')` inside onMount will not work.

```svelte
// App.svelte
<script lang="ts">
  import { Toaster } from 'svelte-sonner'
  import Counter from './lib/Counter.svelte'
</script>

<main>
  <Counter />
  <Toaster />
</main>
```

```svelte
<script lang="ts">
  import { onMount } from 'svelte'
  import { toast } from 'svelte-sonner'

  onMount(() => {
    toast.info('Hello') // not working
  })
</script>
```

By the way, why not provide a method to explicitly import CSS like Bootstrap does? This seems to avoid the issue.

```ts
import 'bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css'
```

comments.body:
Ya, having it integrated in the library reduces a good amount of boilerplate code and ensures a consistent experience across applications using the library. 

But notably, there is one reliability aspect that this PR ensures. On loading persistent toasts we animate only the number of visibleToasts on load so it seems consistent with how the library animates new toasts. While persistent toasts load in we have already set the toastCounter so any new toasts do not overwrite persisted toasts. Since toastCounter cannot be set from outside the library logic, consumer code trying to implement this logic would not be able to guarantee a unique toast ID.  

In summary: Both, animating persistent toasts in, and ensuring unique toast ID's is pretty non-obvious for consumer code to handle.

comments.body:
I don't actually think it's possible to incorporate unless you were encouraging forking?

https://github.com/emilkowalski/sonner/blob/main/src/index.tsx#L101
`const remainingTime = React.useRef(toast.duration || durationFromToaster || TOAST_LIFETIME);`

We don't have access to the Toaster's duration for headless toasts. We also wouldn't be aware of when the timer is paused due to the toast being hovered.

I won't try and convince you that visual timers are a good thing, but I just want to be certain of what I think you're saying: fork this repo.
